page.title: 04ECOLOGY IN PANTON
page.content: The area is extremely rich in most aspects of wildlife despite its mainly arable nature. The woodlands are con- iferous and deciduous.The latter con- sists of mainly oak, ash, beech,birch and maple. Despite field amalgamation, a large number of hedges still remain, providing a rich habitat for wildlife. Small mammals include hedgehogs, rats, and voles. Birds include yelllowhammers, sparrows, blackbirds, thrushes, robins and partridges. The wild flowers are abundant with swathes of snowdrops through the woods up the Benniworth road in early spring fol- lowed by bluebells then forget-me-nots There violets and aconites, cowslips, scabious and purple orchids. There are butterflies but not many varieties: Red Admirals, Peacocks, Gatekeepers and Tortoiseshells and cabbage white.
